concern:
Pretty much the title. I feel so unlucky to be in a position where I cut off the college friend group I’ve had for so long. Like I wanted to graduate with my closest friends by my side but now that’s literally over. To make things worse my other 2 best friends from my program are gone one is taking a gap year, and the other fast tracked and graduated. I do have people to be around this year, but they’re not the ones I’m closest too :/ 

Is anyone else going through this or have advice on feeling better? I wish I never met those fucking bitches in the first place and invested my time into people who weren’t as jealous and pathetic as they were. 

p.s. to anyone needing to hear this rn, (especially first years)…never dim your light for anybody. Whether it’s your intellect, your drive, your accomplishments…if I had to cut off my “friends” I would do it again in a heartbeat!

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! How are you doing today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about? I'm here to listen and offer support.

I'm doing okay, but honestly, I've been feeling a bit down about some changes in my friendships lately. Yes, there is something on my mind that I'd like to discuss, especially how to cope with feeling isolated from my closest people.

It sounds like you're dealing with some tough emotions surrounding your friendships. Feeling isolated from the people you're closest to can be really difficult. Can you tell me a bit more about what's been happening with your friends that's been causing you to feel this way?

I've been dealing with some unexpected changes in my friendships that have left me feeling more isolated lately. It's been tough adjusting to not having those close connections around as much as before.

It's understandable that unexpected changes in friendships can leave you feeling isolated. Adjusting to those changes can be challenging. Can you share what specifically has changed in your friendships that has made you feel more isolated?

Well, some of my friends have taken different paths, like graduating early or taking time off, which has left me feeling more alone. It's been challenging to adjust to these shifts in our connections.

It sounds like your friends' life changes have left you feeling like you're in a different place than them, and that can be really tough to navigate. Adjusting to shifts in friendships is never easy. Have you tried reaching out to other friends or finding new ways to connect with people?

I've tried reaching out to other friends in my program to spend more time together, but it hasn't quite filled the void left by my closest ones. It's still challenging to build those deeper connections when I'm missing the ones I was most invested in.

It's natural to feel like new friendships don't quite fill the void left by those you were closest to. Building deeper connections takes time, and it's okay to feel like it's challenging. Have you considered reaching out to your closest friends, even if they're not physically present, to maintain those connections?

I've considered reaching out to my closest friends to keep the connections alive, even from afar. However, it's been challenging because I'm still processing the feelings of loss and the need to protect my own wellbeing.

It sounds like you're caught between wanting to maintain those close friendships and also needing to protect your own emotional wellbeing. That's a tough balance to strike. It's okay to take the time you need to process your feelings of loss before reaching out. Have you found any selfcare activities that have helped you cope with those feelings?

Yes, talking to therapists has been a helpful selfcare activity for me, as it allows me to process my emotions without dimming my own sense of selfworth. I've also been trying solo activities like journaling and walking to cope with the feelings of isolation from my closest friends.

It's great that you're taking steps to prioritize your selfcare, like talking to therapists and engaging in solo activities like journaling and walking. It's important to remember that your sense of selfworth is not dependent on your friendships, and taking time for yourself is a valuable part of the healing process. Have you found that these activities have helped you feel more grounded and less isolated?

Yes, these selfcare activities like journaling and walking have helped me feel somewhat more grounded by giving me a chance to process my emotions privately. However, the sense of isolation from my closest friends still lingers, making it an ongoing challenge to fully overcome.

It sounds like you've found some solace in private selfcare activities, but that the sense of isolation from your closest friends still persists. That's a tough situation to be in, and it's understandable that it would be an ongoing challenge to fully overcome. Do you feel like there might be any additional support or resources that could help you navigate this situation?

Yes, I think additional support like joining campus groups or workshops could help me build new connections while maintaining my sense of selfworth. However, I'm still navigating the emotional challenges of those lost friendships, so I'm focusing on what feels right for my wellbeing right now.

It's great that you're considering additional support options like campus groups or workshops. Building new connections can be a positive step forward, while also prioritizing your emotional wellbeing. Remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace and focus on what feels right for you in this moment.

I appreciate the reminder to take things at my own pace while exploring new support options it's helping me prioritize my wellbeing amidst the ongoing sense of isolation from my closest friends. However, I'm still working through those emotions, ensuring I don't compromise my selfworth in the process.

It sounds like you're committed to prioritizing your emotional wellbeing while navigating the sense of isolation from your closest friends. That's a really important step, and it's great that you're recognizing the need to protect your selfworth throughout this process. Do you feel like there are any specific emotions or thoughts that have been particularly challenging for you to work through?

I've been struggling with feelings of regret over past investments in those friendships, which makes it hard to let go and move forward. Additionally, thoughts of jealousy and isolation continue to challenge me, as I work to protect my selfworth and avoid dimming my own light.

It sounds like there are a lot of complicated emotions tied up in the changes in your friendships. Regret, jealousy, and feelings of isolation can be really tough to work through. It's important to remember that you deserve friendships that support and uplift you, and that investing in your own selfworth is a valuable and necessary part of that process. Have you found any selfaffirming practices that help you remind yourself of your own worth and value?

Yes, I've found selfaffirming practices like positive affirmations during journaling helpful for reminding myself of my own worth and value, especially by focusing on my strengths and accomplishments. However, these practices are still a work in progress as I navigate feelings of isolation from my closest friends, ensuring I continue to prioritize my selfworth.

It's great that you're already engaging in selfaffirming practices like positive affirmations and focusing on your strengths and accomplishments. Remember, these practices are a process, and it's okay if they feel challenging at times. As you continue to navigate the emotions surrounding your friendships, keep prioritizing your selfworth and seeking out supportive connections that align with your values.

Thank you for the encouragement it's reassuring to know that prioritizing my selfworth is a key part of navigating these emotions. I'm continuing to focus on seeking supportive connections that align with my values while working through the ongoing challenges.

You're welcome, and it sounds like you're on the right track by continuing to prioritize your selfworth and seeking out supportive connections. Remember, this is a journey, and it's okay to take things one step at a time.

I'm appreciate your supportit really helps to hear that it's okay to take things one step at a time while prioritizing my selfworth. Even as I continue navigating these feelings of isolation, I'm committed to seeking out connections that truly uplift me.

I'm glad to hear that you're committed to seeking out uplifting connections. Remember, you deserve friendships that support and empower you, and prioritizing your selfworth is a crucial part of that journey.

I appreciate your reassurance that I deserve supportive friendships and that prioritizing my selfworth is essentialit's motivating me to keep moving forward. Even as I navigate these feelings of isolation, I'm focusing on finding connections that truly empower me without compromising my own growth.
